title: ATO seeks to bankrupt Huang Xiangmo
text:
Mr Huang's lawyers are seeking a modification of freezing orders granted by the Federal Court last month, to carve out all assets he holds outside of Australia, as well as the $12.8 million Mosman mansion owned by Mr Huang's wife, Jiefang Huang.

The ATO has argued that bank records show that Mr Huang transferred to his wife all or most of the funds used to buy the house, which settled on January 29, 2013. Mr Huang is challenging the ATO's position that he is entitled to half of the value of the house.

In an affidavit, Mrs Huang has said that the funds were a gift from her husband.

The house is the main asset in Australia to which the ATO has a claim, after Mr Huang on March 9 removed himself as a beneficiary of the Huang Family Trust, the Yuhu Investment Trust, the Austrump Family Trust, and the 626 Family Trust, which hold the bulk of the family assets in Australia. He was replaced as an appointor of three of the trusts on the same day.

Anthony McInerney, SC, for the ATO, said that in regard to assets held in China or Hong Kong, evidence had been led that enforcement was not likely, but "not impossible".

"It is possible for an Australian bankruptcy to be recognised in Hong Kong," he said.

Mr Hutley said that it was a well known principle that countries including Australia refused to enforce tax orders made by foreign courts and that there was "no prospect" that any attempt to pursue Mr Huang's assets outside Australia would succeed.

"That’s why my learned friend turned to bankruptcy," Mr Hutley said. But foreign courts also did not recognise bankruptcy debts that were based on tax penalties.

He said freezing orders should not be issued where there is no prospect of enforcing them: "These orders are orders of the most intrusive variety."

Mr Haung is the subject of an inquiry by the Independent Commission Against Corruption into allegations that he provided an illegal $100,000 donation to the NSW Labor Party. He has denied making the donation but declined request to testify before the ICAC.

Justice Jagot reserved her decision on the freezing orders until Monday.
description: The Tax Office is seeking to bankrupt the Chinese billionaire and will consider court action in Hong Kong to recover his $140.9 million tax bill.
